pullRequest.body:
Given a meromorphic function on `U`, produce a divisor on `U`. Provide basic simplifier lemmas and establish behavior under (scalar) multiplication and inverses.

We implement this material in a file called `MeromorphicFunction` because future PRs will likely construct divisors attached to meromorphic differential forms.

This material is used in [Project VD](https://github.com/kebekus/ProjectVD), which aims to formalize Value Distribution Theory for meromorphic functions on the complex plane.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [39da8c6cf7](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22819/commits/39da8c6cf70ce1e495010ac2338d7f2b4b0d099c)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.Meromorphic.Divisor.MeromorphicFunction` (new file)|1650|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ apply_eq_zero_of_nmem`
`+ divisor`
`+ divisor_apply`
`+ divisor_def`
`+ divisor_inv`
`+ divisor_mul`
`+ divisor_smul`
`+ order_inv`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>Increase in tech debt: (relative, absolute) = (1.00, 1.00)</summary>

|Current number|Change|Type|
|-:|:-:|:-|
|1|1|bare open (scoped) Classical|

Current commit [39da8c6cf7](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/39da8c6cf70ce1e495010ac2338d7f2b4b0d099c)
Reference commit [fa9f869943](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/fa9f869943415790a14a0884fe3b9dd44643c780)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Won’t have time to review this one, unfortunately.
@girving No worries. Thanks for answering at all!

```suggestion
lemma apply_eq_zero_of_nmem {z : 𝕜} (D : DivisorOn U) (hz : z ∉ U) :
```

```suggestion
    hf.divisorOn z = if hz : z ∈ U then (hf z hz).order.untopD 0 else 0 := rfl
```
`rfl` is also a term (-;

```suggestion
  `order.untopD`. -/
```

```suggestion
lemma divisorOn_apply {f : 𝕜 → E} (hf : MeromorphicOn f U) (hz : z ∈ U) :
```

I advise to make `f` explicit as well.
Lean has the tendency to hide complicated proof terms as ellipsis `...` which can become quite unhelpful if you are trying to figure out which function you are taking the divisor of.

In fact, you could consider defining the divisor for *all* functions, by defining it to be `0` for ones that are not meromorphic. If you decide to do that `hf` will of course remain an argument of most theorems below.
Also: in that case `U` should probably become explicit.

I perfectly understand what you are saying [constantly moving my mouse over the ellipsis to see what function we are discussing], but I need time to form an opinion.

This is a terrible trade-off. On the one hand, ellipsis are a pain. On the other hand, the notation is extremely compact and intuitive as it is. Writing `hf.divisorOn` is so much better than `MeromorphicOn.divisorOn f hf`. I need to experiment a little to see what variant will work for me.

The suggestion defining divisors for all functions has its charm, but might later lead to conflicts when one later tries to attach a divisor to functions in other contexts. I am thinking about divisors encoding growth rates of  (sub)harmonic functions, level sets of Lelong numbers, multiplier ideals in the theory of PDEs, …

Those other contexts will have their own definition, in its own namespace. So I don't think there will be a conflict.

And with `open MeromorphicOn` you would end up writing `divisorOn f hf`, which is maybe not so bad.
Ok, that got me convinced. Implemented according to your suggestion, only writing `divisor` instead of `divisorOn` because I feel if wouldn't be quite obvious what the `On` refers to.

```suggestion
/-- The order of the inverse is the negative of the order. -/
```
This definition is now `divisor`, but all the lemma names still mention `divisorOn`. I think they should become `divisor_*`.
I guess an explicative is in order, but this might lock me out of GitHub. I am on the train now. Will fix as soon as I arrive.
Fixed.
Is "analytic" a well-behaved concept when the target space isn't complete?

I think `nmem` isn't a standard abbreviation in mathlib, `not_mem` is more often seen. (I appreciate that you are just following the existing `Function.nmem_support`, but I think that name is a bit non-standard.)

```suggestion
    simp only [Set.mem_image, Set.mem_setOf_eq, Subtype.exists, exists_and_right,
      exists_eq_right, Pi.zero_apply, dite_eq_right_iff, WithTop.untopD_eq_self_iff,
      WithTop.coe_zero]
    tauto
```

This proof has a non-terminal simp, which is best avoided. Fortunately it can be reordered to avoid it:
```suggestion
  supportWithinDomain' z hz := by
    by_contra h₂z
    simp [h₂z] at hz
```

This subproof starts with a non-terminal simp (best avoided). Here's a workaround:
```suggestion
  · lift (h₁f₁ z hz).order to ℤ using (h₂f₁ z hz) with a₁ ha₁
    lift (h₁f₂ z hz).order to ℤ using (h₂f₂ z hz) with a₂ ha₂
    simp [hz, (h₁f₁ z hz).order_smul (h₁f₂ z hz), ← ha₁, ← ha₂, ← WithTop.coe_add]
```

```suggestion
    divisor (f₁ * f₂) (h₁f₁.mul h₁f₂) = divisor f₁ h₁f₁ + divisor f₂ h₁f₂ :=
  divisor_smul h₁f₁ h₁f₂ h₂f₁ h₂f₂
```
(`smul` is defeq to `mul` when it's a ring acting on itself)

```suggestion
  · simp only [hz, divisor_apply, DivisorOn.coe_neg, Pi.neg_apply, (hf z hz).order_inv]
```

This line puzzles me slightly, since it stops working if you remove the `WithTop.untopD_coe` from the `rw` line, even though `WithTop.untopD_coe` is a simp lemma so it should be getting applied automatically by the `simp` in the next line anyway. It also doesn't work if you change `rw` to `simp_rw`, which is strange.

pullRequest.title: feat: implement the Divisor of a Meromorphic Function
